questions.question: What happens to the width of the depletion region under forward bias?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Forward bias reduces the width of the depletion region.
explanations.b: Correct. Forward bias narrows the depletion region, facilitating current flow.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The depletion width changes with biasing.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The depletion region does not disappear entirely under forward bias.

questions.question: What is the primary effect of reverse bias on the PN junction?

answers.b: It reduces the depletion region width
answers.c: It increases the depletion region width

explanations.a: Incorrect. Reverse bias reduces current, not increases it.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Reverse bias widens the depletion region.
explanations.c: Correct. Reverse bias widens the depletion region, reducing current flow.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Reverse bias does not cause thermal runaway under normal operation.

questions.question: Which parameter has the most significant impact on the built-in potential (V_bi)?

explanations.a: Correct. Temperature strongly influences intrinsic carrier concentration, affecting V_bi.
explanations.b: Correct. Higher doping concentrations increase V_bi.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Forward bias affects the external operation, not intrinsic V_bi.
explanations.d: Incorrect. External resistance does not influence V_bi.

questions.question: What is the dominant current component under reverse bias in an ideal PN junction?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Diffusion current dominates under forward bias.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Recombination is more relevant to forward-biased PN junctions.
explanations.c: Correct. Under reverse bias, generation current dominates in the depletion region.
explanations.d: Partially correct. Leakage current includes generation current but also other minor effects.

questions.question: Why does breakdown occur in a reverse-biased PN junction at high voltages?

answers.a: Thermal effects cause the material to melt
answers.b: High electric field causes avalanche multiplication
answers.c: The depletion region becomes a conductor
answers.d: Doping concentrations equalize across the junction

explanations.a: Incorrect. Breakdown is not caused by melting.
explanations.b: Correct. High electric fields cause impact ionization, leading to avalanche breakdown.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The depletion region remains a barrier but allows large current flow.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Doping concentrations do not equalize during breakdown.

questions.question: How does carrier lifetime affect the reverse recovery time of a PN junction diode?

answers.a: Shorter carrier lifetime increases recovery time
answers.b: Longer carrier lifetime decreases recovery time
answers.c: Shorter carrier lifetime decreases recovery time
answers.d: Carrier lifetime has no effect on recovery time

explanations.a: Incorrect. Shorter carrier lifetimes reduce the recovery time.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Longer carrier lifetimes increase the recovery time.
explanations.c: Correct. Shorter carrier lifetimes reduce the recovery time.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Carrier lifetime is directly related to recovery time.

questions.question: What determines the breakdown voltage of a PN junction diode?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Junction area affects current but not breakdown voltage.
explanations.b: Correct. Higher doping reduces the breakdown voltage.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Carrier mobility affects current, not breakdown voltage.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Intrinsic carrier concentration is unrelated to breakdown voltage.

questions.question: In a heavily doped PN junction, what phenomenon occurs at low forward bias?

explanations.a: Correct. Heavily doped junctions allow carriers to tunnel at low forward biases.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Avalanche breakdown occurs under reverse bias at high voltages.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Thermal runaway is not relevant here.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Ohmic conduction occurs when there is negligible barrier.
